title: Depression Anxiety Stress Scale (DASS-21)
shortDescription: A 21-item self-report questionnaire designed to measure depression, anxiety, and stress.
longDescription: The DASS-21 is a reliable and valid measure of depression, anxiety, and stress. Please read each statement and select how much it applied to you over the past week. The 21 questions are divided into three categories—Depression, Anxiety, and Stress—each containing 7 questions. Scores for each category are calculated separately and matched to severity levels.

questions.text: I found it hard to wind down

options.label: Did not apply to me at all
Applied to me to some degree, or some of the time
Applied to me to a considerable degree or a good part of time
Applied to me very much or most of the time

questions.text: I was aware of dryness of my mouth

options.label: Did not apply to me at all
Applied to me to some degree, or some of the time
Applied to me to a considerable degree or a good part of time
Applied to me very much or most of the time

questions.text: I couldn't seem to experience any positive feeling at all

options.label: Did not apply to me at all
Applied to me to some degree, or some of the time
Applied to me to a considerable degree or a good part of time
Applied to me very much or most of the time

Applied to me to some degree, or some of the time
Applied to me to a considerable degree or a good part of time
Applied to me very much or most of the time

Applied to me to some degree, or some of the time

Applied to me to some degree, or some of the time

Applied to me very much or most of the time

triggers.helpText: If you're experiencing thoughts that life is meaningless or having thoughts of self-harm, please reach out for immediate help. Contact a mental health professional, crisis helpline, or emergency services.
If you're experiencing feelings of worthlessness, please consider speaking with a mental health professional. You deserve support and care.

riskRules.helpText: If you're experiencing significant distress, please consider reaching out to a mental health professional for support and guidance.
